title: Download Option is "Broken"
content:
When it comes to managing downloads in Options/Preferences, one may choose between: 1) Always save in Downloads directory, and filename is default from source 2) Always ask [user] where to save files, and filenames may be customized

Firefox used to remember the last directory files were saved to, and would open that directory to allow me to dictate filename—and it would also remember the folder view of that directory. Now, Downloads are "broken." Every single time Firefox opens the Downloads directory in Grouped by Type Details view, no matter what. It's been doing this for at least three months....

...except...now that I go to reproduce the behavior so that I can accurately document the issue, NOW it decides to behave differently, more like the way it's supposed to. I still want to know how to enforce proper behavior (let's pretend for a moment that it has not decided to behave properly TODAY), and I sure am hoping for something that does not involve a complete reset, where Firefox forgets EVERYTHING I've "taught" it, and I have to start the laborious process of teaching all over again.

I've been using computers since 1978, and Firefox since about a year after it launched (when Netscape died). That's 2003 for those who have to look it up.
creator: Gremlin.Bitten

title: Trouble With Wells Fargo Logon Using Firefox But Not Biing
content:
I've previously had no trouble like this morning's. When I try to log on to https://connect.secure.wellsfargo.com/auth/login/present I get into an endless cycle of entering username and password and getting the response "Must Enter Username to Continue" -- I have no trouble getting into their Customer Service section at https://www.wellsfargo.com/help/.

I went through resetting the password and had a long, unsatisfactory chat with one of their employees, who insisted the problem must be with my browser because, according to her eyeballs, my browser (Firefox) was not hitting their site at all. She suggested I try another browser, which I did. Using Bing, I had no trouble logging on and downloading the info I needed from my account page. She said there was nothing they could do at their end, since the problem is in my browser.

Any ideas?

title: Sidebar scrolling speed suddenly super high
content:
Hi,

since about two versions (I just upgraded to 88 but this started probably a few weeks ago) the scrolling speed in the bookmark list (the bar on the left) has increased about fivefold (this is my own eyeball estimate). This is problematic because I have to be extremely delicate with my finger movement not to scroll the entire list at once : a single flick will immediately get me to the end of the list (which as it stands, spans about 8 times my screen height).

Scrolling in webpages and other places such as preferences page is fine. Other programs didn't change either, it seems confined to Firefox's bookmark list. I use my laptop's trackpad to scroll, and I'm on an up-to-date Windows10. Anyone has an idea what's happening ?

Thanks !

Hadrien

title: Profile Backup Query
content:
Hi,

I want to backup my profile, so I followed the instructions on [Back up and restore information in Firefox profiles]

It says that I should copy the xxxxxxxx.default folder, but I can see 2 folders in the mentioned location.

  1. bxx3v8u9.default-release
  2. yfefhd4p.default

The first folder, bxx3v8u9.default-release, contains many files and sub folders, while the second folder, yfefhd4p.default, contains only 1 file - times.json

According to the article, I should backup xxxxxxxx.default folder, which is the yfefhd4p.default in my case. But, in the same article, under Restoring to a different location, it says Copy the entire contents of the profile folder backup, such as the handlers.json file, prefs.js file, bookmarkbackups folder, etc.

So, do I need to backup/restore both folders?
creator: AkhileshTekade

title: Firefox has problems with saving credentials
content: I hope someone can help with this. Firefox is supplying my login credentials on-screen for an often used secure website, but when I click the login button the credentials are wiped from the screen (ie. login details are now removed) and I am not logged in. If I supply the details manually, Firefox prompts me to update the stored credentials with what I've just typed. I confirm that I want it to do so and continue with the login process. Every time I log in, this sequence of events re-occurs, meaning that Firefox is - failing to use the stored credential (the login fields are blanked out when I click the login button) - failing to update my stored credentials (whenever I supply the details manually, Firefox is triggered to ask if I want to update the stored credentials with what I've just typed, indicating that the stored version is both incorrect and not being updated). Any suggestions on what I should do about this? (I don't have this problem with Safari, which is not my preferred browser.) Many thanks! Jeremy

title: Won the 5 Billionth search on Mozilla
content: What happened: I was looking for used car parts on my laptop. I went to a new window, typed in a new search, and a screen popped up saying I was the 5 billionth Mozilla winner and I had 15 minutes to pick a prize. It told me the last winner won some kind of TV and other entertainment equipment, and after each winner the count resets. I did not really care, but there was no cancel button, or "X" to leave the site. So, I picked a prize and won a $1000 Amazon Gift Card. I forgot to verify a "https://" on the page and gave out private information. The page it went to kept buffering, so I closed it and again without looking to verify it was a secure page. The page I had input my information on was gone and again, not verifying the page was secure I closed it as well. So, I checked my email address and there is no email telling me about the Mozilla win. What do I need to do??? I gave out vital information and have put my HARD earned credit into peril. Recently, I added a Mozilla VPN to my online routine for security. I do not understand how this page was able to pop up on my laptop. Currently, I am very upset and do not know what to do to keep myself and my credit safe. Please help!

title: Option to send a configurable FLoC header?
content:
No, this is not me asking for Firefox to start learning what FLoC cohort I'm in and boost the tracking on the web.

I generally impersonate Chrome when I browse the internet, just to make myself less distinct online. Recently, Google has detected my browser as suspicious when I try to sign in to certain accounts. I assume this is because Firefox is no longer behaving like Chrome, since FLoC does not exist in Firefox. For this reason, I was wondering if there could be a feature where we can randomize the FLoC cohorts Firefox sends out, or configure a specific one to send, to better mimic Chrome.
creator: matthew34

title: Breach advisory
content:
I received the following message today from breach-alerts@mozilla.com: "'On August 23, 2015, ClearVoice Surveys was breached. Once the breach was discovered and verified, it was added to our database . . . " This breach occurred on August 23, 2015, some six years ago, according to the advisory. The advisory lists "Passwords, IP addresses, Phone numbers, Email addresses, Dates of birth, Physical addresses, Additional information, including Genders, Names" as compromised data.

The advisory then says to "change your password" without saying to what site. I am left to assume that means the password to "ClearVoice Surveys." I have no account there nor have I ever had one. How, then, is it possible for all those data points listed above to be compromised? Even if I answered some survey it published, how would it know any of my passwords if I never entered any of them on that site (which I would never do)? Frankly, this advisory posits such an implausible scenario, and an equally implausible solution, as to be useless.

There is no explanation as to how any of the hazards alleged to accompany this "breach" will affect my accounts. If there is a way, then please explain how it is possible for all that data to be accessible to anyone on account of that breach.

title: How Firefox has been acting since last couple of updates
content:
I have a number of bookmarked pages. When I open a new window and then select the bookmarked page i want to open, FF switches tyo another ALREADY OPEN TAB and loads the page there removing the page that was opened. EX: I use both regular FF and Private windows on my screen and switch from one to the other according to the loaded pages I am using. When I open a new tab in private windows and try to get FF to open a bookmarked page, it will switch to my open tabs under regular FF instead of opening the bookmarked page in the new private windows page it will REPLACE an open page. This happens a lot with my YouTube pages which I leave open during the day to listen to binaural beat music in the background while I am working. What's up with that? Why doesn't the bookmarked page open in a new private windows tab?

I also noticed that when I leave pages open during the day in both private and regular FF now (since the most recent update)and go back to them, I often have to reload the whole page instead of just allowing me to go directly to something on that page.

I have been dodging the most recent updates because with each new update there seems to be more and more CONTROL from your side, and less freedom on our side of the screen. Is this purposeful? If so, WHY?!!!
